reviewText:
The Great Fusion is a story set in a near future, where the economical crisis has taken a turn for a worse, making all countries fusionned in one, where riches are richer and where poors are poorer. And the copyright has taken over the world. You're Max, a geek, that lost his job at the beginning of the crisis and despite working, he's depressed and in a poor district. One day, Mate, his friend, finds a CD with Pong on it. But after playing it, Mate is kidnapped.... It's your job to find him!

It's a point-&-click game, with a depressing setting... but also satirical. In reality, the whole story is a parody (and also denouncing) of the mighty copyright. A lot of 'easter eggs' can be found: Larry for Leisure suit Lary, the boss that loves cats, the thugs whose names are directly a reference to video games, etc.. There is however no puzzles apart to find all objects and use them.

The problem of the game is the lack of real objective. There is no indication of what to do. Unless you find the right character to speak with. Also, you can't control your save. If you missed an achievement, you have to begin again the game.

The translation, while very good, has some spelling mistakes. I played the game in French by the way. So, it's also multi-language.

The graphics are cartoonish, reinforcing the comedy settings. The soundtrack is also good.

I got the game through a bundle and I don't regret it. However, to fully enjoy the game, you must have also a good reference of culture (cinema, arts, video games). I'm pretty sure I missed some jokes. I recommend it mainly for people loving adventure games. It may bore others.

reviewText: If you like adventures in the old (and best) style then this game is for you. Similar to masterpieces like Monkey Island or Day of the tentacle, not as good as them of course, but close, the history is very good, really really good, graphics and gameplay similar to old adventures from Lucasarts (but with a history and jokes really good)\nIf you like adventure games, get this one. Now I've to continue playing hehehe...

reviewText: Fun, well-written, old school. A good point n' click shot for a pleasant evening of retro adventure-gaming.

reviewText: I love point and click games like this and this one is OK but it's not great, the storyline is kinda boring to be honest and it doesn't make a lot of sense also the numerous jabs at pop culture are annoying. It's also really difficult to figure out what to do sometimes especially since you quite often have to do the same thing over and over with the same results until it produces a different result. But with that said it's still worth buying. On sale. For when you're REALLY bored.

Point and Click style game, I wouldn't say this is one of the better ones but it's still good enough for a playthrough. I played this in offline mode till the end so my playtime on this title isn't correct.\nFor me 6.5/10, pick it up in the sales or from a keysite.

reviewText:
UPDATE: Steam trading cards are working as intended now.

______________________________________________
No trading cards when promised trading cards makes Homer something something....

What you'd expect from a point and click game, but I've been playing an hour and a half and the only reason I've understood some of the objectives was by seeing the achievements... and even those have dead ended me until I try every combo to make the story proceed. Game is pretty linear and not much freedom to devert from the story, reminds me of the old school Sam and Max Hit the Road / Leisure Suit Larry (no lusty ladies though) to a degree.

For five bucks was worth a go, the game is motivated by politics and copyright laws/big brother, so if that isnt your cup of tea, then you may want to steer clear. Otherwise worth giving it a shot.

reviewText: This is a game about an incredibly average guy who is Definitely Not The Game Developer, living in a near future dystopia in which Every White Male Middle Class Software Engineer's Worst Nightmares Come True.
